docs.lead_paragraph: The president’s appearance at an A.F.L.-C.I.O. Labor Day picnic in Cincinnati kicked off a crucial week for his plans for an overhaul.

headline.seo: Obama, Back in Campaign Mode, Rallies Supporters on Health Care
headline.main: Obama Rallies Supporters on Health Care

docs.snippet: The president’s appearance at an A.F.L.-C.I.O. Labor Day picnic in Cincinnati kicked off a crucial week for his plans for an overhaul.

keywords.value: American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: ''What does all this talk of health care reform mean to me?'' That may sound like a line from one of those vintage ''Saturday Night Live'' monologues by Al Franken, but this is 2009, and the question is a serious one, posed by AARP in a mailing that will arrive in almost nine million homes this week.
docs.abstract: AARP, as part of broader campaign to reassure members that it is committed to protecting their Medicare benefits and that it is neutral clearing house, is mailing out information about what health care reform means (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: As Congress returns to Washington on Tuesday with health care atop the agenda, one puzzle is how the Obama administration will build a supportive coalition. A handful of lawmakers, other than the party leaders, bear watching as the fate of a proposed government-run insurance plan hangs in the balance.
docs.abstract: Brief sketches of handful of lawmakers, other than party leaders, who bear watching as fate of proposed government-run insurance plan is debated; photos (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. David Himmelstein, an associate professor of medicine at Harvard Medical School, is a co-founder of Physicians for a National Health Program and co-author of studies finding that medical bills are a leading contributor to personal bankruptcies in the United States. He spoke to Anne Underwood, a contributor to The New York Times. Q. How many medical bankruptcies are there annually in this country?
docs.abstract: Harvard Medical School Associate Prof David Himmelstein, co-founder of Physicians for a National Health Program, comments on his finding that medical bills are leading contributor to personal bankruptcies in US; photo (S)
